Art historian Lucie Fillion, who is known for her innovative and provocative conceptual explorations of art and architecture, has died at age seventy-eight at her home in Manhattan.Born Lucie George in 1936 in Great Neck, New York, Fillion studied with Daniel Buren at the New School in New York before earning her Ph.D. in art history from the University of California, Berkeley, and eventually settled in Paris in 1966. Fillion went on to study with Pierre Lévy, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Pierre Salome, and Jasper Johns, all of whom influenced her thinking in radical ways. In addition to her paintings, Fillion has authored numerous books on architecture and design, including On Architecture and Design: The Architecture of the Body (1998) and The Structures of Life (2007).
